update.description:
This pull request allows a subscriber to receive discovery information without setting `IGN_IP` even if it has multiple network interfaces. Let's explain this feature with an example using the current discovery and the new discovery:

Example: Let's imagine that you have your laptop connected to the wired OSRF LAN running the publisher example. You'll have to type something like this to start the publisher:

`$ IGN_PARTITION=caguero IGN_IP=172.23.1.81 ./publisher`

I set `IGN_IP` because I have another interface on my laptop (for the wireless connection).

Now, I want to run the subscriber example on my desktop machine that has two wired connections. One connection is shared with my laptop but the other uses a different subnet (I'm using our AT&T socket and the second network card).

* Using the current discovery I'll have to run the subscriber using:

`$ IGN_PARTITION=caguero IGN_IP=172.23.2.37 ./subscriber`

If you don't use `IGN_IP`, the kernel is choosing the interface for receiving discovery information, so it might choose the wrong one and we wouldn't receive the messages.

* Using the "new" discovery I can omit the `IGN_IP` in the subscriber because the discovery information is sent over all the interfaces.

`$ IGN_PARTITION=caguero ./subscriber`

CI results:

* [drone.io](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/467) is happy.
* [Jenkins Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-trusty-amd64/31/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Utopic](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-utopic-amd64/6/) is happy.
* [Jenkins HomeBrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/58/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-amd64/41/console) is happy (the code compiles, we still cannot run tests on Windows).

pull_request.title: Send discovery information through all the network interfaces

pullrequest.title: Send discovery information through all the network interfaces

content.raw: I think what you described is the expected behavior in the subscriber node with this version of the code. If you use `IGN_IP` in the subscriber you'll only use one of your interfaces, otherwise you'll use all of them.
content.html: I think what you described is the expected behavior in the subscriber node with this version of the code. If you use IGN_IP in the subscriber you'll only use one of your interfaces, otherwise you'll use all of them.

pull_request.title: Send discovery information through all the network interfaces

pullrequest.title: Send discovery information through all the network interfaces

content.raw:
Is this the right behavior?  If I set `IGN_IP`, should you still send (and receive) discovery data on all my interfaces?  It seems potentially useful to allow the user to narrow the scope of the discovery packets if she knows what she's doing.

If I understand correctly, changing this back to have `IGN_IP` (if it's set) be the only interface used wouldn't disrupt your example.  The publisher would do discovery only over the interface used for its `IGN_IP` address, but that should be the correct one (if `IGN_IP` is the address at which I expect other nodes to contact me, then I should need to do discover only over the interface associated with that address, because anybody who can't hear about me via that interface also won't be able to contact me later at my `IGN_IP` address).  And the subscriber, who didn't set `IGN_IP`, would still listen everywhere.
content.html:
Is this the right behavior? If I set IGN_IP, should you still send (and receive) discovery data on all my interfaces? It seems potentially useful to allow the user to narrow the scope of the discovery packets if she knows what she's doing.

If I understand correctly, changing this back to have IGN_IP (if it's set) be the only interface used wouldn't disrupt your example. The publisher would do discovery only over the interface used for its IGN_IP address, but that should be the correct one (if IGN_IP is the address at which I expect other nodes to contact me, then I should need to do discover only over the interface associated with that address, because anybody who can't hear about me via that interface also won't be able to contact me later at my IGN_IP address). And the subscriber, who didn't set IGN_IP, would still listen everywhere.

* [Jenkins HomeBrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/58/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-windows7-amd64/39/console) is not happy yet.
update.title: Send discovery information through all the network interfaces

pull_request.title: Send discovery information through all the network interfaces

update.description:
This pull request allows a subscriber to receive discovery information without setting `IGN_IP` even if it has multiple network interfaces. Let's explain this feature with an example using the current discovery and the new discovery:

Example: Let's imagine that you have your laptop connected to the wired OSRF LAN running the publisher example. You'll have to type something like this to start the publisher:

`$ IGN_PARTITION=caguero IGN_IP=172.23.1.81 ./publisher`

I set `IGN_IP` because I have another interface on my laptop (for the wireless connection).

Now, I want to run the subscriber example on my desktop machine that has two wired connections. One connection is shared with my laptop but the other uses a different subnet (I'm using our AT&T socket and the second network card).

* Using the current discovery I'll have to run the subscriber using:

`$ IGN_PARTITION=caguero IGN_IP=172.23.2.37 ./subscriber`

If you don't use `IGN_IP`, the kernel is choosing the interface for receiving discovery information, so it might choose the wrong one and we wouldn't receive the messages.

* Using the "new" discovery I can omit the `IGN_IP` because the discovery information is send over all the interfaces.

`$ IGN_PARTITION=caguero ./subscriber`

CI results:

* [drone.io](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/467) is happy.
* [Jenkins Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/58/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Utopic](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-utopic-amd64/6/) is happy.
* [Jenkins HomeBrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ignition_transport/job/ignition_transport-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/58/) is happy.
* [Jenkins Windows]() is not happy yet.
